sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.title: A Survey on Model Context Protocol: Architecture, State-of-the-art, Challenges and Future Directions
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract: The rapid proliferation of large-language-model (LLM) services is constrained by three long-standing barriers: stateless integration interfaces, ad-hoc security controls, and the absence of a unified mechanism for injecting rich, multi-turn context. The Model Context Protocol (MCP) has been proposed to overcome these limitations through a session-oriented, JSON-RPC framework that allows LLMs to negotiate capabilities, invoke external tools, and retrieve contextual resources under fine-grained, OAuth 2.1-compliant access control. This article provides the first comprehensive treatment of MCP from a communications-systems perspective. We (i) dissect its layered host-client-server architecture, (ii) formalize its lifecycle and transport semantics, and (iii) benchmark official and community implementations spanning software-development, cloud-automation, healthcare, and cybersecurity domains. Open challenges-including transport-layer latency,token-lifecycle overhead, cross-server privilege escalation, and persistent-context tampering-are analysed in depth, and mitigation strategies rooted in cryptographic hardening, edge caching, and capability-graph isolation are articulated. Finally, we outline a future research agenda that extends MCP toward multimodal payloads, Quick UDP Internet Connection (QUIC)-enabled streaming, and post-quantum credential exchange. By synthesizing protocol design with deployment evidence, the article positions MCP as a pivotal enabler of secure, adaptive, and scalable agentic workflows-marking a decisive forward step in the maturation of real-world LLM applications.

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: What are the architectural components and lifecycle of the Model Context Protocol (MCP) in the context of large-language-model (LLM) services?
How do official and community implementations of MCP perform across different domains such as software-development, cloud-automation, healthcare, and cybersecurity?
What are the open challenges associated with MCP, including issues like transport-layer latency and token-lifecycle overhead?
What mitigation strategies can be applied to address the challenges faced by MCP, such as cryptographic hardening, edge caching, and capability-graph isolation?
How can the Model Context Protocol be extended to support multimodal payloads, QUIC-enabled streaming, and post-quantum credential exchange?

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: Survey on Model Context Protocol
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The paper conducts a comprehensive survey of the Model Context Protocol (MCP) from a communications-systems perspective. It involves dissecting the MCP's architecture, formalizing its lifecycle and transport semantics, and benchmarking its implementations across various domains. The study also analyzes open challenges and proposes mitigation strategies, setting a future research agenda for MCP.

studyDesign.designDetails: The study is designed as a survey to evaluate the MCP's architecture, lifecycle, and transport semantics. It includes a cross-sectional analysis of existing implementations and challenges, without the use of control groups or randomization.

procedures.procedureDescription: The procedure involves a detailed analysis of the MCP's layered host-client-server architecture, identifying its components and their interactions.
This procedure formalizes the lifecycle of MCP and its transport semantics, providing a structured understanding of the protocol's operation.
Benchmarking official and community implementations of MCP across different domains to evaluate performance and identify best practices.
In-depth analysis of the open challenges faced by MCP, such as transport-layer latency and token-lifecycle overhead.
Articulation of strategies to mitigate identified challenges, including cryptographic hardening and edge caching.
Outlining a research agenda for extending MCP capabilities, including multimodal payloads and post-quantum credential exchange.
